advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FLYER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.console-picture-page.de" target="_blank">www.console-picture-page.de</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #9</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a German advertisement for the BIT-60 and BIT-90 models. Atari VCS-2600 cartridges are scattered in front of the BIT-60, to show that the BIT-60 is really compatible with the VCS-2600 ! But strangely enough, there is no picture displayed on the TV. Were these models really working ? ;-)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SECOND 6502</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Second Processor option features, in a separate case, a 3 MHz 6502 processor and 64 KB of RAM. It was connected to the BBC system through the Tube channel. The BBC RAM was then used as video RAM, so the full memory area of the Second Processor was available for user programs.<br> Two ROMs was also delivered. The first one holded a new BASIC version called HI-BASIC that made full use of the new memory configuration. The other updated disc or Econet filling system.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8BS.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROUD !</strong></font><br><blockquote>This authentic picture show a proud owner of a Wren transportable computer ! It looks like it bought it 5 minutes ago as he doesn't really know from which side to handle it...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3 (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In March 1983, the price of the assembled version decreased of $20 ($79.95 instead of $99.95)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1946...</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an extract of the promotional guide. It says: <br><br> <font color="#666666">1946... Today the TO 7<br> 1946: 30 tons, 160 m²<br> Today: 3.5 Kg, 0.01 m²</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Students have a heap particularity which we cared about"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Each day, go on the computing road''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Basic, It is magic"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tim_K for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Byte magazine</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEO-GEO ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://spoonman.roarvgm.com/neogeo/" target="_blank">SpoonMan's Neo-Geo page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #14</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPARISON CHART #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> METACARD AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The MetaCard was the first card allowing an Apple II owner to run IBM-PC programs and MS-DOS, CPM/86 and UCSD operating systems.<br> It used a 5 MHz. 8088 processor, 64 to 128 KB of RAM and a dedicated powed supply unit.<br><br> It was priced at <b>$980</b> (64KB version) and <b>$1,150</b> (128 KB). </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (FEB. 1980) </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert show the built-in user menu and system status.<br><br> The right located system is the dual-drive version.<br> The left one is the 10 MB hard-disk version.</blockquote>

computer.description:
The Wondermega was released in 1992 as a joint development by Sega and JVC. It is similar to the Multi-Mega, being a combination of a Mega Drive and Mega CD, but with the added ability to function as a karaoke machine and improved sound thanks to JVC's new DSP. The system shipped with four karaoke programs and a compilation CD of four games. Two microphones can be connected to the system so users can sing along with CDs, or, thanks to a button on the machine, the CDs vocals can be muted allowing you to sing with just the music as a backing track.
In 1993 the WonderMIDI package was released. This allowed users to connect a MIDI keyboard the Wondermega to create sound effects and music, and included instructional software which could help people learn to play the piano. 1993 also saw a re-release of the system, with several small changes designed to reduce cost.

emulator.description: Kega is a Sega SG1000, SC3000, Master System, Game Gear, Genesis/Megadrive and SegaCD/MegaCD emulator for Win9x/ME/2000/XP
emulator.name: KEGA

item.description: the action chair||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE ACTION CHAIR</strong></font><br><blockquote>The action chair is a rare item. Connected to a Genesis/Megadrive, it acts as a controller! When you lean backward/forward it tells the Genesis to go down/up and when you lean left/right it tells to go left/right. Two handles on each side offer two buttons each, resulting in 4 buttons : START, SELECT, A & B. <br><br> The Action Chair is basically a chair mounted on a controller. It is thus possible to play all games with it, though it is more convenient to play games like After Burner II, Space Harrier II, Super Thunder Blade, Hang on, Road Rash, Super Monaco GP, etc.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Spycal</b> for this picture</p></blockquote>

Documentation|||Page 1|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> DOCUMENTATION</strong></font><br><strong>> Page 1</strong><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Spycal</b> for this picture</p></blockquote>

Documentation|||Page 2|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> DOCUMENTATION</strong></font><br><strong>> Page 2</strong><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Spycal</b> for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.name: Wondermega
computer.ports: cartridge, AV out, MIDI, headphone jack, 2 MIC jacks, Expansion port, 2 controller ports
computer.sound: Yamaha YM2612 6 channel FM, 4 channel PSG, JVC DSP, 1 bit DAC
